Robin Cook died over the weekend at the age of 59.
He was the former British foreign secretary who resigned from Tony Blair's government to protest the war in Iraq.
Cook delivered his resignation speech in the House of Commons on March 18th, 2003, just before the invasion.
(Soundbite from speech)
I intend to join those tomorrow night who vote against military action now.
It is for that reason, and that reason alone, and with a heavy heart that I resign from the government.
(In unison) Hear!
Hear!
Robin Cook was a Scotsman, a longtime member of Parliament and a passionate voice for the Labor Party.
He collapsed and died while hiking up a mountain in the Scottish Highlands on Saturday.
Robin Cook's fellow parliamentarian Menzies Campbell, deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, calls Cook the most accomplished debater the House of Commons had seen for many years.
He had a remarkable, almost forensic, ability to get right to the very heart of an argument.
And in our political tradition in the United Kingdom of adversarial politics, debating is a very, very important part of the armory of the successful politician.
Robin Cook could take on opponents across the House of Commons chamber and destroy them literally.
What about his international outlook?
He was foreign secretary from '97 to 2001, which overlapped with the crisis in Kosovo, something he seemed to have taken great pride in helping to resolve.

He certainly did well on Kosovo, but it has to be said on the other side of the balance sheet that he made some unguarded remarks in the Asian subcontinent which got him into a great deal of trouble both from the Indian and the Pakistan governments.

And in the Middle East he caused quite a lot of difficulty because he went and he paid a visit to a disputed settlement without going previously to Yad Vashem--to the memorial to those who lost their lives in the Holocaust, which is a necessary thing for any British politician to do whenever they visit Israel.
There's a sense in which he was a better politician in opposition than he was a politician in government.
Were you surprised when he did resign as leader of the House of Commons in 2003?

I wasn't surprised because I knew from my conversations with him that he shared many of the reservations which I and my colleagues in--not just the Liberal Democrats, my own party--but all other parties shared about the wisdom of military action against Saddam Hussein.
I don't think anyone expected him to make a resignation speech of such extraordinary quality and integrity.

It was a masterpiece of its kind, but, of course, when he sat down, if you looked very carefully, you could see that he was brushing a tear from his eye because he was essentially a member of the Labor Party.

The Labor Party was his political lifeblood, and for Robin Cook, whose affiliation to the Labor Party was so important to him, to be arguing against his party in public and then to be resigning from its government, that was an act of very great political courage, but for him an act of very great political emotion as well.
Did you talk to him after he resigned about how he felt about leaving the government of Tony Blair?
The following day I voted with him in the lobby.
Together we went into the lobby to vote against his government and Tony Blair.
And I had a brief discussion with him, and it was clear to me he still found the whole idea of behaving in that way--voting against his own government--deeply emotional and deeply troubling.
But there was no doubt about his view as to whether it was--whether or not it was the right thing.
He was firmly convinced that principle and integrity demanded that he should do what he did.
Menzies Campbell, thanks very much for talking with us.
It's been a pleasure talking to you.
Menzies Campbell, deputy leader of Britain's Liberal Democrats, remembering Robin Cook, the former British foreign secretary who died while hiking in Scotland on Saturday.
Cook was 59.

How is fast fashion harmful to the environment?

The industries that we need to create those materials are things like agriculture.
We need agriculture to grow cotton.

Polyester comes from the oil industry.
We have, obviously, issues associated with the extraction of oil.
And then to convert those fibers, that raw material, into the garments you're wearing, we have energy-intensive processes such as yarn spinning, turning that fiber into yarn.
